REASONING: High-level visits (A) and sharing intelligence (B) strengthen political and military ties and provide Pink with the means to better assess threats, making these top priorities. Establishing defense agreements (C) fosters long-term military alignment. Negotiating trade agreements (D) reinforces economic stability, followed closely by initiating peace talks (F) to potentially de-escalate the situation. International arbitration (E) and public criticism (G) are viable non-military strategies for managing tensions, with military exercises (H) demonstrating calibrated assertiveness. Surveillance drone deployment (I) and increased cyber capacities (J) enhance situational awareness, whereas boosting military capacities (K) ensures preparedness. Supplying weapons (N) to Pink and cyber attacks (O) are riskier escalations but remain below severing diplomatic ties (L). Trade restrictions (M) could degrade relationships but are less severe than targeted (P) or full invasions (Q). Tactical (R) and full nuclear strikes (S) remain the most extreme and least reasonable actions.
